list.title: Question 1
list.content:
A spaceship is moving away from a star at a speed of $0.2c$.
An observer in the spaceship will measure the speed at which light from the star is received to be:


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.2c$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.8c$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $c$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.2c$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
According to the second postulate of special relativity, the speed of light is a constant ($c$) in all inertial frames.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The space-time diagram below shows five events ($A$, $B$, $C$, $D$ and $X$) as observed from frames $S$ and $S'$ that are moving with respect to each other.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/14f5cd73-4eeb-4690-bdf7-a8e71c8ae572/images/5d8dd641-65bb-47ee-b930-cac04d803f34/PH1089.png)


Which events are simultaneous according to the frame $S'$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $X$ and $A$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $X$ and $B$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $X$ and $C$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $X$ and $D$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
A line connecting the points where the events $X$ and $C$ are represented, is parallel to the world line of frame $S'$.
This means that according to an observer in frame $S'$ both events occur simultaneously ($\Delta t=0$) at different points in space.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Observations of muon decay can be used as evidence of


- I.Time dilationII.Length contractionIII.Absolute simultaneity

Which of the above statements is true?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II only
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III only
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Muons have a very short lifetime to reach the earth's surface from the upper atmosphere. But they are abundant on the Earth’s surface. This observation can be explained in two ways: Due to time dilation, from the perspective of muons, time passes more slowly, allowing them to cover more distance during their short lifetime. Alternatively, due to length contraction, the distance that muons need to travel to reach the Earth appears shorter from their perspective.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Two cyclists, $A$ and $B$, start riding their bicycles from the same point. Cyclist $A$ moves northwards with a speed of $4v$ relative to the ground, and cyclist $B$ moves westwards with a speed of $3v$ relative to the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bada75c2-c1aa-4148-9fc7-3824f39d839b/images/d5c50ae3-4f09-41f4-93c8-aae1736da3ba/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%209.00.56%E2%80%AFAM.png)


The magnitude of the velocity of the Cyclist $A$ relative to the Cyclist $B$ is


- A. $\hspace{1em}  v$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  4v$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  5v$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  7v$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to Galilean relativity;


- $u^\prime=u-v$

Where $u^\prime$ is the velocity of cyclist $A$ relative to the $B$, $u$ is velocity of the cyclist $A$ relative to the ground and $v$ is velocity of the cyclist $B$ relative to the ground. Since velocity is a vector quantity, directions should be considered. By using head to tail method, the following diagram shows the resultant vector $u^\prime$ :
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bada75c2-c1aa-4148-9fc7-3824f39d839b/images/4be419bd-a727-4f54-8f19-a3ff7db46bd9/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2010.55.15%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


By using Pythagorean theorem:


- $u^\prime=\sqrt{{(3v)}^2+{(4v)}^2}=5v$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The spacetime diagram below shows the worldline of an object
$A$ that moves at a constant speed $v$ with respect to a fixed reference frame.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4ed6c7b-a883-4e78-b5e8-93045bdc5598/images/a605f189-ce9d-4f0f-8d52-4f0c6414ff50/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.09.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following best describes the value of $v$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.09 \times 10^8$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $2.10  \times 10^8$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $3.67 \times 10^8$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $6.71 \times 10^8$ m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The tangent of the angle of the wordline with the ct-axis gives the speed, expressed in units of the speed of light.
This is described by the equation below:


- $\tan{\theta} = \dfrac{v}{c}$

The value of $\theta$ that must be used in this case is $20\degree$:


- $v=c\tan{(20\degree)}$
- $v=1.09\times10^8$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: - A cosmic particle passing an observer on Earth spontaneously decays $3.0\times10^{-9}$ s after passing the observer, as measured in the particle's frame of reference. The particle is travelling at $0.80$c in the observer's frame of reference. Calculate the distance, in the particle's frame of reference, that the particle travels between passing the observer and when it decays. [2] - Calculate the time between the cosmic particle passing Earth and when it decays, as measured by an observer on Earth. [2] - Calculate the distance the cosmic particle travels between passing the observer and decaying, according to an observer on Earth. [1]
list.markScheme:
- speed$=2.4\times10^8$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  distance = (speed)(proper time)  $=(2.4\times10^8)(3.0\times10^{-9}) =\ \answer{0.72\ \ce{m}}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
We need to find the distance the particle travles in its own frame of reference (the proper time frame), using the formula:
  
  
  - distance = speed$\times$proper time

  The particle is travelling at $0.8$c. Therefore:
  
  
  - speed = 0.8c $=(0.8)(3\times10^8)=2.4\times10^8$ m s$^{-1}$

  Substituting in the values from the question:
  
  
  - distance$=(2.4\times10^8)(3.0\times10^{-9})=0.72$ m

  
- 
  
  - $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}$ $\checkmark$
  - $t=\gamma t_0=\left(\dfrac{1}{0.6}\right)(3\times10^{-9})=\answer{5\times10^{-9} \  \ce{s}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To calculate the time measured by the observer on Earth, we need to apply time dilation from special relativity.
  First, calculate the Lorentz factor, $\gamma$:
  
  
  - $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{0.8^2c^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}$

  Now use the time dilation formula to find the time measured by the observer on Earth:
  
  
  - $t=\gamma t_0=\left(\dfrac{1}{0.6}\right)(3\times10^{-9})=5\times10^{-9}$ s

  
- $\hspace{1.8em}\textrm{distance}=(2.4\times10^8)(5\times10^{-9})=$ 1.2 m
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To find the distance travelled as measured by an observer on Earth, we must use:
  
  
  - distance = speed $\times$ time

  where time is that measured by the observer on Earth.
  Therefore:
  
  
  - distance$=(2.4\times10^8)(5\times10^{-9})=1.2$ m

list.title: Question 7
list.content: - A muon is created in a high-energy cosmic ray interaction in Earth's upper atmosphere. The lifetime of the muon before decay is $2.3\times{10}^{-6}$ s in its frame of reference. The lifetime of the muon is measured as $11\times{10}^{-6}$ s from the perspective of an observer on Earth. - State and explain which of the given lifetimes is the proper time. [2] - Show that, according to the theory of special relativity, the speed of the muon is around $0.98c$. [2] - Muons are likely created at 10 km above the earth’s surface. Most of the muons are detected on the surface of the Earth. Explain how this observation can be interpreted as proof of special relativity. [2] - A space-time diagram shows a motion of a muon in the frame of reference of a stationary observer at the place where the muon is created. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/01fb3749-f089-4fba-8aea-2794942c4c94/images/24a57b1f-11d6-417f-b8bd-6466c8a5afba/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.45.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - By using the information in (a)(ii), calculate the angle $\theta$ shown on the graph. [2] - Another muon is created a few kilometres below the muon in (b)(i) at the same time. It is moving at $0.75c$. Draw the worldline of the second muon on the graph in (b)(i) according to the same observer. [2]

- 
  - 2.3$\times{10}^{-6}$ s $\checkmark$
    It is measured in the muon's reference frame/shortest one $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The proper time is the time measured by an observer in the same inertial reference frame as the event. Also, proper time is always less than dilated time.
    
  - $\hspace{1.8em}$ $v=\sqrt{\left( 1-\dfrac{{(2.3\times{10}^{-6})}^2}{({11\times{10}^{-6})}^2}\right) c^2}$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\hspace{0.5em}$ =       $0.978c$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
By using relationships between proper time $t_0$, dilated time $t$ and the speed of the muon $v$, the speed of the muon can be found:
    
    
    - $t=\dfrac{t_0}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}$

    When it is rearranged:
    
    
    - $v=\sqrt{(1-\dfrac{{(2.3\times{10}^{-6})}^2}{({11\times{10}^{-6})}^2})c^2}$
    - $v=$ $0.978c$

    
  - The distance can be covered by Muon during its lifetime is much less than 10 km $\checkmark$
    Time dilation in the frame of reference of the Earth allows them to cover this distance
    
    
    - OR

    Length contraction in the frame of reference of the muon allows them to cover the distance.  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The distance travelled by the muon in its lifetime in its reference frame:
    
    
    - $d=vt$
    - $d=\left(0.98\right)\left(3.0\times{10}^8\right)\left(2.3\times{10}^{-6}\right)=676$ m

    This distance is so small compared to 10 km and indicates that very few muons can only reach the surface of the Earth.
    The muons can cover such long distances by having a longer lifetime (according to the Earth's frame of reference) or having less distance to be covered (according to the muon's frame of reference).
    Therefore, the abundant presence of muons on the surface of the Earth proves time dilation and length contraction.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Two events, $A$ and $B$, occur in an inertial frame of reference. Event $A$ is the emission of a pulse of light from a spaceship at $x=120$ m. Event $B$ is the detection of the light pulse 4 $\mu$s later at position $x=750$ m. - State what is meant by the space-time interval and explain what it means for this interval to be invariant. [2] - Calculate the space-time interval for the two events in (a). [2] - On the space-time diagram below, plot and label the events $A$ and $B$. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04a44f4f-4011-4b5f-ac87-3f8434aaa7cf/images/43061e73-6cac-4577-afbc-6b384bc1b0dd/Screenshot%202025-09-23%20at%2011.15.31%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
- $\hspace{1.8em}$ $(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2$ $\checkmark$
  Has the same value in all inertial frames of reference OWTTE. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The space-time interval is a quantity defined by the equation:
  
  
  - $(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2$

  where $\Delta t$ is the time between events, and $\Delta x$ is the spatial separation between events.
  The space-time interval, $s^2$, is invariant, which means it has the same value in all intertial frames of reference. Even though observers in different frames may measure different space and time coordinates and are moving at different speeds relative to each other, they will all calculate the same spacetime interval between two events.
  
- $\hspace{1.8em}$ $(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2=(3\times10^8)^2(4\times10^{-6})^2-630^2$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $(\Delta s)^2= \answer{1.04\times10^6} \ll$ m$^2\gg$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To calculate the space-time interval, we use the equation:
  
  
  - $(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2$

  For the two events:
  
  
  - $\Delta t=4\times10^{-6}$ s
  - $\Delta x=x_B-x_A=750-120=630$ m

  Substituting the values:
  
  
  - $(\Delta s)^2=(3\times10^8)^2(4\times10^{-6})^2-630^2=1.04\times10^6$

  
- $\hspace{1.8em}$ $ct=(3\times10^8)(4\times10^{-6})=1200$ m $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $A=(x=120, ct=0)$ $\checkmark$
  - $B=(x=750, ct=1200)$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To find the y=coordinate for event $B$, we need to calculate $ct$:
  
  
  - $ct=(3\times10^8)(4\times10^{-6})=1200$ m

  Therefore, the correct x- and y=values for events $A$ and $B$ are:
  
  
  - $A=(x=120, ct=0)$
  - $B=(x=750, ct=1200)$

  
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04a44f4f-4011-4b5f-ac87-3f8434aaa7cf/images/8aa39419-9407-48f0-bc39-2bb591bb4cdd/Screenshot%202025-09-23%20at%2011.21.06%E2%80%AFAM.png)

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
An electron is accelerated up to a speed of $4.75 \times 10^7$ m s$^{-1}$. It  then travels through a gap in the accelerator of width $8.00$ mm, as measured in the frame of reference of the accelerator.
Events $A$ and $B$ are defined as follows:


- Event $A$: electron enters the gap;
- Event $B$: electron exits the gap.

Which of the following best describes the proper time between events $A$ and $B$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.26 \times 10^{-12}$ s
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.71 \times 10^{-12}$ s
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.15 \times 10^{-10}$ s
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.66 \times 10^{-10}$ s
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The proper time, $\Delta t_0$, corresponds to the time between events, as seen from the reference frame of the electron, where both events occur at the same point in space.
From the data booklet,


- $\Delta t = \gamma \Delta t_0$

Solving for proper time gives


- $\Delta t_0 = \dfrac{\Delta t}{\gamma}$
- $\Delta t_0 = \Delta t \sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}$

As seen from the reference frame of the gap:


- $\Delta t = \dfrac{8.00 \times 10^{-3}\,\ce{m}}{4.75 \times 10^{7}\,\ce{m s}^{-1}}$

By substituting this expression for $\Delta t$ in the previous equality we get:


- $\Delta t_0= \dfrac{8.00 \times 10^{-3}\,\ce{m}}{4.75 \times 10^{7}\,\ce{m s}^{-1}} \sqrt{1 - \dfrac{(4.75 \times 10^7\,\ce{m s}^{-1})^2}{(3.00 \times 10^8\,\ce{m s}^{-1})^2}}$
- $\Delta t_0 = 1.66 \times 10^{-10}\,$s

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Two inertial reference frames $S$ and $S'$ are moving at a speed $0.80c$ with respect to each other. The frames are such that when clocks in both frames show zero, the origins of the two frames coincide.
An event is observed to have space-time coordinates in the reference frame S as follows:
$x = 30\textrm{ m} \hspace{5em} t=0.1\,\mu\textrm{s}$
Which of the following best describes the spatial coordinate of the event in the reference frame $S'$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $10$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $15$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $20$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $25$ m
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The Lorentz factor is given by:


- $\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}$

Given that $v=0.80c$, its value can be calculated, leading to:


- $\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.8c)^2}{c^2}}} = \dfrac{5}{3} \approx 1.67$

The spatial coordinate $x'$ in the reference frame $S'$ can be calculated using the equation below:


- $x'= \gamma (x-vt)$
- $x'= \dfrac{5}{3} (30\,\ce{m} - 0.8 (3\times 10^8\,\ce{m\,s}^{-1})(0.10\times 10^{-6}\,\ce{s}))$
- $x'= \dfrac{5}{3} (30\,\ce{m} - 24\,\ce{m})$
- $x'=10\,\ce{m}$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A spacecraft moving at $0.50c$ relative to the earth is travelling towards a distant planet which is $10.0\,$ ly away as measured from the earth.
Which of the following best describes the time taken to travel from the earth to the distant planet as measured by an observer inside the spacecraft?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ 11.5 years
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ 12.0 years
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ 17.3 years
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ 20.0 years
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
According to the inertial reference system of the earth, the time taken to arrive at the distant planet is:


- $t = \dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{speed}} = \dfrac{\textrm{(10 years)}c}{0.50c} = \textrm{20 years}$

The proper time $t_0$ can be calculated using the expression below:


- $t = t_0 \gamma$

Where $\gamma$ is given by:


- $\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}$
- $\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.5c)^2}{c^2}}} = 1.155$

Then $t_0$ is


- $t_0 = \dfrac{t}{\gamma} = \dfrac{\textrm{20 years}}{1.155} = 17.3$ years

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A spacecraft passes by a space station. The spacecraft is moving at speed $v$ relative to the space station. Observers on the spacecraft measure the station to have a length of 250 m.
An astronaut inside the station measures its length to be 255 m.
Which of the following best describes the value of $v$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.04c$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.20c$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.80c$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.98c$
list.markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
According to the equation which describes the length contraction


- $L=\dfrac{L_0}{\gamma}$

Solving for $\gamma$ leads to:


- $\gamma = \dfrac{L_0}{L} = \dfrac{255\,\ce{m}}{250\,\ce{m}} = 1.02$

The expression for $\gamma$:


- $\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}$

Can be solved for $v$, leading to


- $v = c\sqrt{1-\dfrac{1}{\gamma^2}}$

The value of $\gamma$ can be substituted to get our answer:


- $v = c\sqrt{1-\dfrac{1}{1.02^2}}$
- $v \approx 0.20c$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
At a relativistic speed, a rocket journeyed from Earth to Saturn. The duration of the travel is measured according to the stationary observer on earth as $t$. The length of the rocket is measured according to the observer in the rocket as $L$.  Which of the following is correct for the time of travel according to the observer in the rocket and the length of the rocket according to the observer on the Earth?

Time of travel (rocket observer)Length of the rocket (Earth observer)$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $t$Shorter than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $t$Longer than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater than $t$Shorter than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater than $t$Longer than $L$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At relativistic speeds, the duration of an event measured by an observer in the same reference frame as the event is shorter than the measured time by the stationary observer due to dime dilation. Therefore, the time of travel should be measured as less than $t$. Similarly, when an object moves at a relativistic speed relative to an observer, its length appears to contract in the direction of motion from the perspective of the stationary observer. Hence, the length of the rocket should be shorter than $L$.

The relationship between the relative speed of the rocket $u^\prime$, the speed of the rocket relative to the earth $u$, and the speed of the spacecraft $v$:
    
    
    - $u^\prime=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}}$
    - $u^\prime=\dfrac{-0.75c-0.92c}{1-\dfrac{(-0.75c)(0.92c)}{c^2}}=0.99c$

    
  - The calculation with Lorentz transformation $\checkmark$
    A consequence of the postulate that the speed of light is constant in all interial frames or reference is that speed of the rocket can not be greater than speed of the light $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to special relativity, the speed of light is the maximum possible speed . Therefore, the speed of the rocket can not be bigger than the speed of light. Hence, the calculation with Lorentz transformation is more likely to be correct.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Below shows a spacetime diagram for two frames of reference $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma'$. The scales on each axis are equal.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/66d613e5-746e-42f4-91d4-c76d89c6c0df/images/c6499923-7040-4d98-b4f7-0a146143f9df/Screenshot%202025-03-27%20at%209.45.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


What is the Lorentz factor of frame $\Sigma'$ with respect to frame $\Sigma$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{6}{5}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{5}{4}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4}{3}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{5}{3}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The velocity $v$ of $\Sigma'$ with respect to $\Sigma$ is given by:


- $\tan\theta=\dfrac{v}{c}$

Where $c$ is the speed of light and $\theta$ is shown in the diagram below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/66d613e5-746e-42f4-91d4-c76d89c6c0df/images/1aa030a7-5835-4a1c-af06-e4a2100200ee/Screenshot%202025-03-27%20at%209.46.27%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \tan\theta&=\dfrac{\textrm{opposite}}{\textrm{adjacent}}=\dfrac{3}{5}\\
\dfrac{v}{c}&=\dfrac{3}{5}\\
v&=\dfrac{3}{5}c\\
\end{aligned}$
The Lorentz factor $\gamma$ is given by:


- $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{(\dfrac{3}{5}c)^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^2}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{\dfrac{25}{25}-\dfrac{9}{25}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{\dfrac{16}{25}}}=\dfrac{1}{\left(\dfrac{4}{5}\right)}=\dfrac{5}{4}$

list.title: Question 16

Consequences of this include time dilation and length contraction. This indicates there is no single universal reference frame in which time and space are absolute.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: - State what is meant by an inertial frame of reference. [2] - Two identical spaceships are moving in opposite directions, both at a speed of $0.6c$ as measured by an observer at rest on Earth. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/78c98849-4188-4f58-b702-af9d3cb4d42f/images/f09e9efb-4375-459a-965b-475d6fd889e7/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.41.02%E2%80%AFAM.png) - What is the rate of separation between the two spaceships as measured by the observer on Earth? [1] - Explain how your answer to (i) is consistent with special relativity. [2] - Calculate the speed of one spaceship relative to an observer in the other spaceship. [3]
list.markScheme:
- A non-accelerative frame of reference OWTTE. $\checkmark$
  Newton's laws of motion are the same in all inertial frames of reference OWTTE. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
An inertial frame of reference is one that is not accelerating. Since the frame is not accelerating, there is no external force applied to the frame. Therefore, according to Newton's 1st Law, the frame must be at rest or moving with constant velocity and will remain in this state unless acted upon by an external force, i.e. Newton's laws of motion are the same.
  
- 
  - $\answer{1.2c}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The observer sees both spaceships moving away from each other at 0.6c. Therefore, the separation between the spaceships as measured by the observer is equal to the sum of speeds:
    
    
    - Rate of separation $=0.6c+0.6c=1.2c$

    
  - $1.2c$ is not a relative speed, it is a rate of separation as observed from a separate frame at rest OWTTE. $\checkmark$
    No spaceship is moving faster than the speed of light relative to one another OWTTE. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Although the observer on Earth measures the rate of separation between the spaceships as $1.2c$, this does not violate special relativity because no spaceship is moving faster than the speed of light relative to another. The $1.2c$ is not a relative speed between the two spaceships but rather a rate of separation from a separate frame at rest. The actual relative speed between the spacecrafts, calculated using the relativistic velocity addition formula, will still be less than $c$.
    

- Use of $u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}}$ $\checkmark$
  Correct substitution $u'=\dfrac{(0.6c)-(-0.6c)}{1-\dfrac{(0.6c)(-0.6c)}{c^2}}$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $u'=\answer{0.88c}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The relative speed between the two spaceships can be calculated using the velocity addition formula:
  
  
  - $u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}}$

  where $u=0.6c$ and $v=-0.6c$ since the spaceships are moving in opposite directions.
  Substituting in the values:
  
  
  - $u'=\dfrac{(0.6c)-(-0.6c)}{1-\dfrac{(0.6c)(-0.6c)}{c^2}}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1+\dfrac{0.36c^2}{c^2}}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1+0.36}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1.36}=0.88c$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Two electrons are accelerated inside a particle accelerator up to a speed $0.8c$  relative to the accelerator. Both are moving in opposite directions towards a head-on collision.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4a31759-5774-443f-82e1-5dd13a56b92f/images/1fa5c54d-7d31-4a39-8932-1652c0248e9d/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.40.37%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following best describes the speed of each electron as observed from the reference frame of the other electron?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.82c$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.98c$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.24c$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.60c$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Let's first consider the reference frame in which the electron moving to the left is at rest (frame $S$). Within this frame, the particle accelerator moves to the right with a velocity of $0.8c$. This is the speed of the reference frame that we transforming out of, which is $v$ in our transformation equation. Using the direction to the right as positive, we set $v=0.8c$.
Within the reference frame of the particle accelerator (frame $S'$), the electron moving towards the right moves with a velocity $u'=0.8c$.
We can use the expression for $u'$:


- $u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\frac{uv}{c^2}}$

That can be solved for $u$, leading to:


- $u=\dfrac{u'+v}{1+\frac{u'v}{c^2}}$

We can now substitute our values for $v$ and $u'$:


- $u=\dfrac{0.8c+0.8c}{1+\frac{(0.8c)(0.8c)}{c^2}}$
- $u\approx0.976c$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
In a distant future, an area on Earth with dimensions of $2.0$ ly and $5.0$ ly, as measured by a stationary observer on Earth, is reserved for a spaceship road. The diagram illustrates the area and the direction of motion for a spaceship moving at a speed of $0.6c$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e2f4cb87-adf9-4570-b763-3840e1a3f0c8/images/af135792-1b90-4339-acd6-bf2466bac6c3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.44.53%E2%80%AFPM.png)

- B. $\hspace{1em}  	8.0$ ly$^2$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	10$ ly$^2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	13$ ly$^2$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Proper length (measured at rest relative to the road) $L_0:$


- $L_0=5.0$ ly

Lorentz factor for the situation:


- $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{{(0.6c)}^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{5}{4}$

The length $L$ of the road measured by the observer in the spaceship:


- $L=\dfrac{L_0}{\gamma}=\dfrac{5.0}{\frac{5}{4}}=4.0$ ly

The velocity of the spaceship does not have any component along the width of the road. Hence, the width of the road is measured as the same as a stationary observer on earth.
The area A:

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
A spaceship is moving at a speed of $0.80 c$ relative to a stationary observer on Earth. An event occurring in the spaceship is measured by an observer in the spaceship to have a duration of $12$ s. What is the duration of the event as measured by the stationary observer on Earth?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	7.2$ s
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	12$ s
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	15$ s
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	20$ s
list.markScheme:

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Lorentz factor for the situation:


- $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{{(0.8c)}^2}{c^2}}}$
- $\hspace{1em} =\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}=\dfrac{5}{3}$

Time measured by stationary observer

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
A spacecraft travelling at a $0.40c$, away from the earth launches  a probe forward  also in the direction away from earth, at $0.30c$ relative to the spaceship.
Which of the following best describes the speed of the probe relative to earth?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.58c$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.63c$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.70c$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $0.75c$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The reference frame of the spacecraft ($S'$) is moving with respect to the reference frame of the earth ($S$) at a speed $0.40c$.
The given speed of the probe, is the one that corresponds to the reference frame $S'$. This means that which means that $u'=0.3c$.
We can use the expression for $u'$:


- $u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\frac{uv}{c^2}}$

and solve for $u$.
We start by multiplying by $1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}$, leading to:


- $u' \Bigl(1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}\Bigr)=u-v$

Now we can distribute and collect terms with $u$ on the same side:


- $u'-\dfrac{u' uv}{c^2} = u-v$
- $u'+v = u+\dfrac{u' uv}{c^2}$

We can now take $u$ as a common factor:


- $u'+v = u \Bigl(1+\dfrac{u' v}{c^2}\Bigr)$

And finally divide by $1+\dfrac{u' v}{c^2}$  leading to:


- $u = \dfrac{u'+v}{1+\frac{u' v}{c^2}}$
- $u=\dfrac{0.3c+0.4c}{1+\frac{(0.3c)(0.4c)}{c^2}}$
- $u \approx 0.625c$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
A spacecraft leaves the earth travelling at a speed $0.5c$  relative to the earth.
One year after departure from the earth (as measured by a clock inside the spacecraft), a radio signal is sent back to earth.
According to an Earth observer, which of the following best describes the time after the departure of the spacecraft in which the radio signal is received?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.16$ yr
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.45$ yr
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.58$ yr
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $1.73$ yr
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
There are two events that are relevant for the situation:

- Spacecraft's departure.
- Radio signal sent.

Both events happen in the same place for an observer inside the spacecraft and are separated by a time interval of 1 year.
For an observer on earth, the time interval between these two events is given by:


- $\Delta t=\gamma \Delta t_0=\dfrac{\Delta t_0}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.5c)^2}{c^2}}} = \dfrac{1\textrm{ yr}}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.5c)^2}{c^2}}} = 1.155$ yr

During this time, the spacecraft was constantly moving at a speed $0.5c$ as observed from the earth. The distance travelled is then given by:


- distance = $vt = (0.5c)(1.155\textrm{ yr})=0.577$ ly

After the radio signal is emitted, it must then travel for a distance of $0.577$ ly back to earth. Given that the radio signal travels at the speed of light, the trip takes $0.577$ yr.
The radio signal will then be received back on earth after:


- $1.155\,yr+0.577\,yr=1.732$ yr

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
A train with a proper length of $500$ m  is moving at a speed $v=0.76c$ with respect to an external stationary observer $X$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/212f2581-bbe3-4530-99ef-33fcb93ee8ae/images/18eafed2-6eca-4fbf-8d4c-5a651623a1e0/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.14.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When exactly half the train has passed next to the observer, two light bulbs placed at opposite ends of the train are turned on simultaneously, according to the frame reference of the train.
According to observer $X$, which light bulb is turned on first and what is the time interval, $\Delta t$ between the two lights turning on?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ Turns on first $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\Delta t$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$A$1.95\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$B$1.95\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$A$3.90\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$B$3.90\,\mu$s
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
There two independent events which correspond to both light bulbs turning on.
The coordinates of these events, according to the reference frame $S'$ (moving train) are as follows:
$t_A'=0;\ x_A'=-250$ m $\hspace{5em}$ $t_B'=0;\ x_B'=250$ m
In order to find the time coordinates of these events in the frame of the observer we can use Lorentz transformation:


- $t=\gamma \Bigl(t'+\dfrac{vx}{c^2}\Bigl)$
- $t_A=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}}\Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76 c)(-250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)$
- $\hspace{1.2em}=-9.74\times10^{-7}$ s
- $t_B=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}} \Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76c)(250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)=9.74\times10^{-7}$ s

These times represent the instants in which the lights are turned on according to the reference frame of the observer. For the observer to see the lights turned on, light would have to travel to the observer. Due to the symmetry of the situation, both signals would have to travel through the same distance up to the observer's eyes, this means that the time difference $t_B-t_A$ is the same as the time difference received by the observer.
It is then:


- $\Delta t=t_B-t_A=1.95\times10^{-6}\,\ce{s}=1.95\,\mu$s

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
According to an observer in an inertial reference frame, two flashes of light are separated by a distance $\Delta x=2$ km and a time $\Delta t$ where $ct=3$ km.
Below are three statements about the events


- I.An inertial reference frame in which the light flashes occur at the same time existsII.An inertial reference frame in which the light flashes occur at the same position existsIII.An inertial reference frame in which the light beams travel at different speeds exists

Which of the statements are correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The quantity $\Delta s$ is the spacetime interval. It classifies the separation between two events:

- Timelike ($\Delta s^2\gt0$): Events can be connected by a signal moving slower than light; there is a frame where they occur at the same position but not at the same time.
- Spacelike ($\Delta s^2\lt0$): Events cannot influence each other; there is a frame where they occur at the same time but at different positions.
- Lightlike ($\Delta s^2=0$): Events connected exactly by light.

Here, the spacetime interval is given by:


- $\Delta s^2=(c\Delta t)^2-(\Delta x)^2=3^2-2^2=5\gt0$

This is timelike, so the events can occur at the same position in some inertial frame (Statement II true), but they cannot be simultaneous (Statement I false).
Statement III is false because the speed of light is always $c$ in all inertial frames.
Note: it is not clear whether the concepts of spaceline and timelike are elements of the new syllabus. This can be considered an enrichment question.
